title: (Super)latus
body: This works features two identical protagonists who are mutually critiquing each other with superlative adjectives, positives and negatives. Both counterparts become increasingly pixelated, censoring one another and disappearing over time. This work puts at stake the notion of critical subjectivity and the self-cancelling quality of such criticism. The vile for some may well be valuable to others. Even though it's often sterile, such criticism may sometimes create fertile antagonistic appreciations and clashes that result into third definitions.

title: Inter[...]Views
body: The work INTER[…]VIEWS is a series of videos found on the internet drastically re-edited. What remains from the original video is an abstract speech emptied out of its former subject matter outlining in this way the phatic expressions of the speaker. Consequentially the media is extremely censored. In these videos the spokesperson is caught in the moments where he/she is rhetorically thinking about what will be said and how. In turn, subtle signs of personal gesture and social conventions more forcefully emerge and render substantial the gap between language and idea.

title: Dirt

slides.legend: Installation view of the work Dirt, New Cross, London, 2012

medium: Carbon & oil on glass, writing from the audience
body:
DIRT is a participatory installation that emerged from observing the numerous vitrines of small shoppings left empty in countries such as Portugal, Spain and Italy after the European crisis late 2009. The idea was to reproduce the dust from the pollution left on the glass. People would leave comments, drawing as reminiscence of the time passing by and the fact that nothing is changing. 

The building chosen for the work was the Ben Pimlott Building from Goldsmiths College, designed by Will Alsop, achieved in 2005. It’s very corporate aspect doesn’t reflect the neighbourhood of New Cross where it was built. During the opening of the MFA final show in 2012, the audience spontaneously wrote messages adding in this manner meaning to the piece. This intervention was also a way to echo the protest of students against the governmental cuts, occupying the building in 2010.

title: Full Stops

slides.body: <iframe src="//player.vimeo.com/video/83450978?title=0&byline=0&portrait=0&color=ff6000" width="1000" height="562" frameborder="0" webkitallowfullscreen mozallowfullscreen allowfullscreen></iframe>

body: ‘Full Stops’ is a musical arrangement made from the last notes of hundreds of the most famous classical songs downloaded on the Internet. Blending all classical eras from Baroque to Romantic passing by Classic, the work produces improbable encounters, including Mozart († 1791) and Tchaikovsky († 1893), Handel († 1759) and Rachmaninoff († 1943). The result is a new harmonious symphony, sometimes pompous, sometimes meditative, which begins and ends indefinitely, again and again.

title: Best Of Best Of Best Of
body: Best Of Best Of Best Of is a series of songs from various musicians and music bands. Each songs is a cumulative crescendo of the best of each artists turning into a cacophony. The work is shown within the form of an album listenable on iPod.

title: Emoticons

slides.legend: Emoticons series, installation view, BYCR gallery, Milan, IT, 2013

body: The emoticons are the most widely used international language symbolising emotions. It first appeared when typewritten texts largely expanded and then with the era of mobile phones and of live chat on the Internet. These icons are being used here within the language of monochrome paintings. The emoticon has been turned into a palpable object. This hyperbolic manner of showing emoticons intends to stimulate the audience to reflect on our daily-mediated relationship to each other, whether it is in a superficial or profound way. The emoticons are sort of emptied out symbols. Their primordial iconicity fades away as we use them in a daily basis. One could say that the more we use an emoticon the less it actually represents our emotional state. It’s, however, not always the case, the emoticons do still carry a profound power of self-reflectivity. Displayed within the traditional white cube, the Emoticons series doesn’t leave indifferent. They continuously inspire a reaction. Whether the viewers smile or not, they are caught in a ceaseless play on signs and signification since the emoticon exists at this strange edge between pure abstraction and representation.

title: Ellipsis
body: In a text, the ellipsis is signalled by 3 dots and brackets (…) which indicates when an author takes out some parts of an original text that is quoted in order to follow the logic of the argument. This absence is inevitably catching our attention and our mind eventually creates something to feed the gap. It is this lack in content of a text that the performance Ellipsis intends to question. The performance is made of 3 black dots covered with faux-fur hanged on a wall carefully and slowly shaved-off by the performers. As the ellipsis, the work is created through a subtraction of some of the original material. This antithetical action contrasts with traditional painting where commonly the material (paint) is added onto the canvas to generate new meanings. It also and mainly emphasis on how the “left un-told” becomes a condition for multiple. In this case, the ellipsis is not only the representation of a silent omission but also enhances a creative and fertile process, unfolding a variety of meaning, exploiting the void until it becomes productive.

body: The word epideictic (epidittico in Italian) comes from the ancient Greek epideiktikos based on deiknunai, which means ‘to show’. It is one of the three subdivisions of rhetoric as described in Aristotle’s book Rhetoric (367 – 322 BC). Epideixis is characterized by or designed to display rhetorical or oratorical skill. Epideixis is a demonstrative speech commonly used for opening events, anniversaries, births and funeral orations. Aristotle and many philosophers after him define Epideixis as a speech of style from which neither agonistic achievement nor polemic arouses. An epideictic oratorical demonstration does not provoke controversy but promotes values that are shared in the communities.

title: Balloons
body: The Balloon's Sculptures are simple metaphorical shapes expressing the confrontation between two languages, the agencies of the materials employed and the structure's layout.

title: Livestock
body: Livestock is a performance made at Goldsmiths College in 2009 that marks a transition between the 2 years work on the series Sweat Dreams and a new body of works opening up on different other mediums - performance, video, sculptures. It’s composed of an installation of 2 chairs, 1 salt painting representing a sheep, a hairdryer. The performer seated on the first chair makes a speech quoting Winston Churchill on notions of tradition, then licks half of the sheep painting, kneeling in front of it, dries the canvas out with the hairdryer and sits on the second chair.

title: Balloon#1
body: This performance explores the idea of exhaustion. The performer sited on a chair blows up a balloon and eventually disappear behind it. This monotonous task operated demands that the audience watches for a long time in order to know the end which is inevitable.

title: Green Pea (Balloon#2)
body: This performance explores the idea of exhaustion. The performer sited on a chair blows up a balloon and eventually disappear behind it. This monotonous task operated demands that the audience watches for a long time in order to know the end which is inevitable.

title: Sweat Dreams
body: The initial idea of this series of paintings was to reproduce the white traces left by human sweat on dark cloths when, for example, one makes sports or dance during hours. Painting, here, is conceptually and literally referring to a physical effort or labour; painting as work. With this technique the various visual references to art history amalgamate with improbable other references forming a mix of different languages uniformed aesthetically within one body of work. Like these non-perennial traces of salt on canvas, all the images have one thing in common: their potential disappearance.

body:
Waterproof was a group show organised by Manuel Publication in 2013.

Press release in french

Existe-t’île?
Vivant dans un hors temps, reflux entre deux eaux, pour ce Manuel #3 nous cherchons le paradoxe insulaire entre la France et la Suisse. À travers les îles, murs et passerelles de la mer :un horizon à notre portée.
L’île est l’image d’un autre monde, repli mystérieux, riche de mythes. D’Alcatraz aux Bermudes, en passant par les Caïmans, ces bouts de terre entourés de mer sont à la fois espace de refuge ou de conquête. Charmant paradoxe, l’ambivalence créée par son autonomie aiguise notre curiosité. Prenant la forme d’un territoire vierge ou d’une zone interdite, qu’il soit celui d’une découverte permissive, ou Atlas d’un anti-monde, l’imaginaire que renvoient les territoires insulaires est riche d’Ailleurs. Zone utopique d’un monde coupé de la civilisation, elle devient le symbole d’une autonomie affranchie, terre d’autarcie résistant aux forces consuméristes, terrain de jeux pour Robinson en devenir ...
Espace d’interstice, l’île se caractérise comme une brèche, une possibilité de fonctionner autrement. L’isolement n’est pas seulement une question d’éloignement : L’hypo-insularité désigne ces îles ou zones dont l’autonomie dépasse les critères purement physiques. L’importance des connexions avec l’autour, modifie la sensation d’isolement et propose une alternative expérimental de la communication. Les kilomètres ne sont plus seuls facteurs d’isolation. En reliant les îles à un flux (tel des satellites) il se crée une nouvelle mise en réseau économique, social ou utopique. Elle est physique autant que fictive elle existe lorsqu’il s’agit d’une zone isolée, à part et peu accessible, «elle existe au milieu du temps, la possibilité d’une île».

title: (Super)latus

slides.legend: Installation view of (Super)latus, HD videos on iPads, 20 minutes, 2013
Installation view of FULL STOPS, Sound Piece on wireless headphones, 20 minutes, 2013

body:
This solo show took place near Geneva City Center in a house that was about to be destroyed in order to start the construction of habitation buildings. 

Curated by Nelly Haliti, the Tivoli Kunsthalle was a series of solo shows in her own house, as a response to the limited spaces in Geneva for young artist to show their works. 

Three bodies of works where shown, INTER[...]VIEWS, as a double projections, FULL STOPS, installed on two wireless headphone in the garden and (SUPER)LATUS, a two channel video shown on iPads.

body:
This group exhibition, held at Galerie B-312 in Montreal, was only visible on USB sticks that the audience could take home in order to watch privately each works of each anonymous artists from the show under numbered folders.

The work proposed was a webpage that would give access to a webcam installed in the solo exhibition ELLIPSIS at La Scatola Gallery in London during the same time as the show in Montreal. People would be able to watch the exhibition in London as voyeurs from Canada. 

Exhibition curated by Maud Marique, Vincent Routhier & Alexandre

title: Ellipsis

slides.legend: View of the works EMOTICONS, fabric on shaped stretchers, since 2011 & EGGTIMER (BALLOONS#5), latex & pinewood, 2012

body:
Press Release

La Scatola Gallery is pleased to present Ellipsis, a compilation of new and continuing works from Stéphane Blumer's fieldwork in the realm of object, medium, and the dimensions of expression.

As abstractly metonymic as they are directly childish in rudimentary expression, emoticons have more and more pervasively (and perversely) peppered messages. By removing these symbols from their text-based homes and inserting them, black, big and bleakly, onto white gallery walls, their significance to feeling and function is monochromatically magnified. Blumer’s translation of fundamental images of emotion back into a stark, complex language is a compelling commentary on the communication between humans and their seemingly always winking minds.

A highlight from Blumer’s oeuvre, ‘Balloon’, will also be on display. This piece, like much of his work, shows the artist’s interest in the constant, excessively curious compromises that humans must make with the materials granted to them, and in the bargains the elements must make amongst themselves.

Blumer’s work communicates its subtle and straightforward messages through a combination of precise experimentation and the chances that well-defined research provides. La Scatola Gallery would like to invite you to partake in this exciting artist’s discussion with spheres that would otherwise remain incommunicable and without shape.

An exhibition curated by Valentina Fois
Text by Chris Piegza

title: The Face Of The Shape
body:
Press Release

Without the innovative approaches to medium that a handful of up-and-coming artists have displayed, La Scatola Gallery could not have so fully realised its first-year ambitions.

La Scatola Gallery is pleased to present a group exhibition with the best multinational emerging artists working in London, Rebecca Ackroyd, Stéphane Blumer, Balint Bolygo, Ronin Cho, Blue Curry, Daniel Eatock, Rowena Harris, Hirofumi Isoya, Hannah Catherine Jones, Jukhee Kwon, Fabio Lattanzi Antinori, Russell Maurice, Steven Morgana, Alicja Pytlewska, Tal Regev, Lisa Selby, Richard Stone, Sarah Tew, Dominic Wilcox, Kentaro Yamada, Gyeong Yoon An.

At a time when ‘mixed media’ has become a blanket with which to cover and obscure the formerly well-defined and hard-fought realms of sculpture, painting and installation, any working definition of medium becomes both abstruse and all-inclusive. Rather than abide complacently within the abyss of namelessness, ‘THE FACE OF THE SHAPE’ will showcase a new era of sculpture, one that does, in fact, mix media to explore form, but also embraces each dimension, of space and of concept, more fully, in contour, craft and narrative, than its recent predecessors. To highlight the success both of the gallery and of the pioneering practices of a select group of artists, La Scatola is pleased to present ‘THE FACE OF THE SHAPE’.(...)
Although each artist’ s young ouevre is individually intriguing, it is the ambition of this group show to accentuate the new course that they are taking sculpture in. Whilst unable and unwilling to label the astounding differences between each featured artists’ aspirations, this show presents a common vision of expression through sculpture. Please join us as the gallery and the artists welcome the new directions shaping the future of form.

An exhibition curated by Valentina Fois
Texts by Chris Piegza

title: Dobra
body: Dobra was a double solo show with Sofia Lopes Borges at Flausina, an independant art space in Lisbon, PT. It was a collaboration with S for Seward in the form of a live concert/performance with the work INTER[...]VIEWS.

body.title: Folklore
body.body: This group show emphasised in a satirical way on the notions of folklore. The work shown was a diptych of two painting inspired by the work of Manuel Krebs new design for the Swiss bills, Bank Of Switzerland. It was later rejected to be realised as real bills, because, inter alia, of the skull on the 1000 note.
